Replying to @philhawksworth 2018-09-08 15:55
A few people have asked me what I did to make this so fast. The answer is: nothing. I just didn't add anything to make it slow. I kept it simple. The pages are pre-rendered. The CSS is inlined. I didn't add unnecessary javascript. The work was done before you got there.

Replying to @siwalikm 2018-09-05 12:46
@siwalik @Netlify Happily not. Since any sites that you deploy on @Netlify are #JAMstack sites which are able to be served directly from our global CDN, there is no server to put to sleep. The assets are cached and served from the edge of the CDN without you needing to manage that yourself.

Replying to @mr_ligi 2018-09-03 15:06
@mr_ligi @pedrouid @Netlify @letsencrypt True. @github apps have introduced that, although that was not previously the case, which is why we implemented this in the least intrusive way available, never receiving creds. The process of creating a well integrated @GitHub app takes a little time. (but watch this space! 🙂)

Replying to @mr_ligi 2018-09-03 14:41
@mr_ligi @pedrouid @bmann @MPtherealMVP @Netlify @letsencrypt Just an FYI on those GitHub repo permissions requested - I understand the hesitancy... sadly the GitHub API isn't more granular than that. So we just grant that access on the client (never sent to the Netlify servers) just in that session to create a webhook on the repo.
